nodes.bodyText:
AFAIK, _lock.runLocked(() -> _exchange) must capture this and therefore allocates each time.
It may or may not be optimized by allocating only the first time it's executed, however the try version you suggest does not allocate ever, but it's more boilerplate-y.

I don't think we should be allocating for syntax sugar.     If we can't demonstrate that these simple getters/setters are not optimised to not allocate, then I think we should use the boilerplate version.... it's only 3 extra lines.
Uh, no. I won't write another method just for this, if you don't want to allocate ever, just use the try version.
this debug is now outside of the lock
Yes, it only references local variables and does not need to be inside the lock.
why ignored ?
Because otherwise IDEs report it as a warning because it's an unused variable.
As I said below (above), that's a problem with the IDE.  The variable is used in the virtual finally block.  Let's just call it lock and raise a bug on the ide

Leave it as ignored, it's not a variable that is used.
Many different kinds of tooling will complain if we leave it as lock (checkstyle, findbugs, and error_prone will all complain)

It is not ignored.  It is used.    I'm not going to change our code for bad tooling.   Checkstyle has not complained about this before???  If it does, then raise bugs on the tools as they should not complain if the variable is an AutoCloseable.
@joakime absolutely not. That lock is used! Calling it "ignored" makes it look like it is not used.
I'm not happy with this change: why are we testing classloader instead of oldClassLoader?
What's the significance of the change here? This method used to be synchronized, and now there's not even a lock?
Why have you removed direct access to the field _classLoader?
Why have you removed direct access to _classLoader?
I actually preferred this the way it was:   the stateChangeCompleted condition makes it very clear what is being awaited and released

I don't like this new method as it allocates a new Condition on every lock??  So at the very least that is garbage.... but does it even work so one locker is going to have a different condition to another?   I think this is just wrong?
If you want to avoid the extra field to hold a condition then you need a class AutoLockWithCondition... and maybe AutoLockWithBiCondition

Ah ignore this... I misread the code.
Still not a fan of this though.
Don't remove this synchronized.   The StringBuffer is synchronized no matter what we do, so the outer synchronized prevents the lock being grabbed and released for every call.
Don't remove this synchronized
This change may be correct - need to run tests to be sure - but I'd really rather you hadn't changed this in a pr which is about locking.
Why was the synchronization on this not replaced with a lock?
Same as for doStop(), where is the lock?
Why removed?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -376,15 +376,12 @@ public static void append(StringBuilder buf,
                               int offset,
                               int length)
     {
-        synchronized (buf)

nodes.bodyText: Where's the lock equivalent to the synchronize?
Where's the lock equivalent to the synchronize?
Lock?
Lock?
Lock?
As this is the base-class for many other classes, do we want to consider allowing access to this lock instead of declaring yet another lock in the subclasses?
It was a private lock, so lets keep it a private lock.
Maybe this lock should be moved down into Resource, the base class?
Where's the lock and why did you change the substance of the code?
Where's the lock, and why did you change the substance of the code?
Again, this might strictly be correct, but should have only been changed after the synchronization is converted to locks.
Unnecessary object allocation of the list here?
What's the motivation for this code change?
Why is the name of the method changed?

We should make this change for all of our Serializable classes.
https://product.hubspot.com/blog/java-11-dont-rely-on-generated-serialversionuid
Opened as Issue #5100
interesting.  is there a reason for this here?

Yes, few lines below there is a naked call to _lock.await() which can only happen if the caller of blockForContent() is holding the lock. The assert makes explicit that we want blockForContent() only ever called with the lock held.

This looks odd.
It looks like we are attempting to modify an immutable field in the request object?
That can't be right.
🤣 @gregw

Always been there, and asked to not do other changes that were not related to synchronization.
I may still have slipped a few though.
I think i've seen this go from Long.toString() to none to back again in multiple commits on this PR.
Been asked to not do other changes that were not related to synchronization.
Huh? Why is this synchronized?
The old code (on the left) called the signal on the AutoLock, this change does it on the flush.
Ditto.  changed from AutoLock.WithCondition.await() to flush.await()
Here too. (l confusion?)
the old code did signalAll on the lock
the old code did signalAll on the lock

static final is all caps by checkstyle rules.
grandfathered ruleset is __<name> (two underscores).

this is a unrelated change.
"clear" (verb) means "to remove unwanted items"
"clean" (verb) means "make (something or someone) free of dirt, marks, or mess, especially by washing, wiping, or brushing"
Using "clean" here is not correct.

Unrelated change.
Please revert.

Unrelated change.
Please revert.
See other comment about "clear" vs "clean".

Bad javadoc. (merge both sections)
Where did this text come from btw?
@lachlan-roberts we should fix this in 10.0.x
This wasn't synchronized before, why now?

Why is this synchronized now?
Wouldn't that mean all of our code using StringBuilder would now need synchronized now to make any use of this change?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -376,12 +376,15 @@ public static void append(StringBuilder buf,
                               int offset,
                               int length)
     {
-        int end = offset + length;
-        for (int i = offset; i < end; i++)
+        synchronized (buf)

nodes.bodyText: This seems like an unrelated change.
This cast shouldn't be needed.
This cast shouldn't be needed.
This cast shouldn't be needed.
This cast shouldn't be needed.
This cast shouldn't be needed.

This will create a new static Timer for every instance. It will replace the previous instance, but it will be held in memory by the thread.
Either keep code as is, or make it statically initialised.
I'm not really sure we need this lock.... but best to keep logic as is for this PR.
